content: hey guys why lock here this week we're
gonna make a macron - this was inspired by Marcus Muller I did a youtube search
for necron - world terrain and his was one of the first search results very
cool little video a lot of ideas packed into it so here's my interpretation on
his building ok so I started with one inch thick extruded polystyrene also
known as home insulation available at any home improvement store
cut a rectangle that is 16 by 12 inches and then I cut out two notches as you
see in this diagram I used my proxxon hot wire table to cut those out but it
can be done with a knife if the blade is fresh and you go slowly now I wanted
each tier to be a certain thickness and it's not 1 inch
ordered them taller than that so a standard humanoid or infantry couldn't
see over the first floor I wanted it to be line of sight blocking so I needed to
increase the thickness and to do that I cut slabs of double corrugated cardboard
and hot glued them on notice the hole I cut here originally I was thinking about
doing a lighted feature but later I called it off anyway I then cut a big
piece of foamboard and remove the notches same as before
and attach this with white PVA glue just Elmer's so you could just use a thicker
foam from the start but I didn't have that and so I just made do then a hot
glue it on some more foam blocks to build the second floor here's the
diagram for it and again cover it with double corrugated cardboard and a single
solid piece of foam board third floor exact same thing and here's the diagram
for it I'm gonna use chipboard
this is graphics medium chipboard my favorite stuff check the link at the
description below anyways we're gonna work around the building cutting pieces
to cover all the vertical surfaces now you should always strive to use a large
piece wherever possible to minimize seams again with chipboard start cutting
some square and rectangular shapes and not glue them on the side mix it up big
ones small ones l-shaped ones double stacked ones be creative and if
you have seams to cover these panels are the opportunity to do that base the
whole thing in black just cheap craft acrylic then you could use a normal
brush but I use my airbrush apply a chaotic swirl of a dark green color so
it's not a full base coat it's a deliberately irregular smattering cover
all the surfaces of the building vertical and horizontal then do the same
with a medium green but only for the floors leave the walls alone and finally
a third time with lime green again leave the walls alone and so you get this
then they used a hex stencil loaded some
black into the airbrush and began covering the top so the result is this
kind of looks like green glowing radiating hexagons back to the walls
we're going to use our medium green again but apply a heavy dry brush you
want to use a bigger brush and allow the fibrous surface of the chipboard and all
the weird shapes to do the work for you it's pretty cool it's like ancient green
metal then onto a lime green color another dry brush but much lighter
mostly just let the edges catch it it's pretty cool I like this look again
chipboard has a slightly fuzzy surface and it does a lot of detail working for
us just by being that way speaking of which more chipboard cut a lot of
quarter-inch wide strips and begin working your way around the floor
perimeters chopping them to size as needed so these are gonna be covering
the ugly scene where the walls meet the floors paint them before attaching them
I used a metallic silver gunmetal whatever and then hot glue them into
place this ensures that you have no chance of getting silver on the floors
by mistake time to hot glue all the stairs in go ahead and do that and it
was at this point that I realized I forgot to film myself making the stairs
so here's a diagram showing how they're made it's pretty logical use double
corrugated cardboard stack decreasing rectangles together and clad the
corrugation features to put together here first cut
out for each of these two shapes hot glue them together to get this beacon
Lantern sort of thing T's hot glue all over it in a swirling pattern and then
hot glue on some thin cardstock strips to cover all the seams I'd recommend
just attaching them too long and then trimming them to size with scissors
after attaching them it's easier than measuring so here we go with all the
banding attached then some foam squares hot glued to the top and bottom base all
those swirls in white then apply a solid coat of yellow followed by a very patchy
coat followed by a very patchy swirly application of a neon green base all of
the banding and black and painted up by dry brushing various greens just like we
did for the main building now I'm gonna make use of my proxxon hot wire table
set it to a very slight angle and run a block through it four times to get a
nice beveled pedestal not shown did the same thing for this much taller skinnier
piece and those both get the ancient green metal treatment as well now I
attach them together with a toothpick and no glue this is because in storage
or when being transported it's gonna be a fragile feature so I just pop it on
the toothpick when it's time to play I was really tempted to call it dumb I
mean I was happy with it but then I figured well let's try and
make it a look a little more weather so pools of white glue placed strategically
flock with construction sand here it is after drying and after
dumping the excess paint with burnt umber slightly watered so that it sinks
in nicely and then a dry brush with tan and lastly just some plain black into
the airbrush and hit all the corners to create some shadows and sort of blend
the surfaces together a little better and we're about to go to the table to
look at the finished product but real quick some reminders there's a link in
the description below for my storefront has all the tools and supplies that I
recommend and for all you 3d printers out there why LOX crafting vids is
sponsored by Heroes hoard which has an excellent range of high-quality models
including but not limited to Altru tiles lines which are open lock compatible
also check out my modules over on the DMS guild and remember three-dollar
patrons get free copies of all my releases anyway see the steps were
chosen specifically so that those thirty two millimeter bases would fit the whole
thing is a pretty big piece its imposing it makes for a good centerpiece things
that do differently maybe revisit the dry brush there at the end maybe use the
dry brush and spray some air in to brown and make it look a little dustier those
patches look kind of isolated and of course I had to do a weird stack up of
different materials to get to the exact height I wanted again that was for a
line of sight blocking but two inch foam certainly would have been easier if you
liked this particular project here's two more that you should go check out right
now also enjoy this month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe
and click that Bell reminder icon I am why lock thanks for joining me and I'll
see you next time you
